item.title: On Holding things lightly - Weeknotes: 16 - 22 Sep
item.description: I am reminded of a story I read as a child as I reflect on this last week. Kids were getting terrified of a snake in a field when they want to play there. One day, a sage passed through the field, observes this, and suggests the snake to ease off, and let it share the field with all others. Snake listens, and stops resorting to aggression. Over the next few months, the kids, the passer-bys and others get accustomed to the now insipid snake. Some kids even start using it as a toy, thrashing across the field and so on. Sage – on his return from his travels –passes through the field again and realises the sorry state of the snake. It tells the snake that his advice to her was not to be aggressive and selfish, but he never meant her to become the opposite and become submissive, retired, insipid.

item.title: S2E11 #Weeknotes Mar 11-17 '24
item.description:
Crikey, this week’s been good, both at the office and at home. Let’s unpack the highlights:

The Work Front

Nearly 5-ish months in the deep end covering for my boss, Vice-President, PMO – what a ride! I’ve been reflecting on the impact I’ve made and how to keep that momentum going across different projects.

Speaking of big-picture stuff, we’ve kicked off the 3-year planning exercise. This is essentially a roadmap for the next three years, helping us chart our course and prioritise initiatives. Companies do this for a few reasons: to anticipate future trends, ensure alignment across departments, and make sure we’re all rowing in the same direction. The process itself usually involves a mix of top-down direction and bottom-up input – think strategy sessions with senior leadership and feedback loops from individual teams.

item.title: S2E10 #Weeknotes Mar 04-10 '24
item.description:
Looking back on the week, it’s been a whirlwind of activity both professionally and personally. Let’s dive into the highlights:

Professional Reflections:

As you know, the economic landscape has been undergoing some seismic shifts lately. With the end of the era of “free money” and the closure of zero interest rate policies, businesses are feeling the squeeze. In the tech industry, where costs often took a backseat to other revenue streams, there’s now a renewed focus on the bottom line. The talk of the town revolves around layoffs, potential recessions, and the need for prudent financial management.

item.title: S2E09 #Weeknotes Feb 26-Mar 03, '24
item.description:
2024 is already rolling, and this past week provided a handful of experiences that will definitely stick with me. Let’s jump right in!

SOFEA and the community spirit: My organisation, Informa, runs a fantastic initiative by offering employees four days of paid volunteer leave to contribute to a cause of their choice. As we began the year, I looked for ways our technical program management team could bond outside of work. Brainstorming another project solution didn’t feel right, so using a day to support a local charity was a clear choice.

item.title: S2E08 #Weeknotes 19-25 Feb'24
item.description:
Meta reflections on writing these #weeklynotes

While the underlying purpose has always been “to reflect on the past week, to go forward into the next week with intentions”, I dabbled with multiple formats for writing these #weeknotes. I might never settle on one format, but I am drawing back on the inspiration from Philippa Perry’s book, “How to Stay Sane”, for the foundational principles: that to remain stable yet flexible, coherent and yet able to embrace complexity, and to thrive in this world, these #weeknotes help me in: a) self-observation, b) relating to others, c) managing stress (as the right kind of stress creates positive stimulation), and d) listening/amending the personal narrative. While I chop the reflections into personal/work boxes, the key themes are the same.

item.title: S2E07 #Weeknotes 12-18 Feb'24
item.description:
Personal Reflections:

It’s gratifying to write for others, and I appreciate your readership. Last week, I started sharing my fortnightly newsletter Des/Pardes more widely. Strangely enough, there’s a duality of feeling: a feeling of self-indulgence balanced by a desire to share/be heard. The positive feedback from readers has been validating, and I’m committed to maintaining consistency while using writing to reflect on myself, the community, and our shared space.

This week also saw a renewed focus on coding practice, spcefically on control structures and efficient error handling. I firmly believe that I have a lot to learn, and I don’t think that drive will never fade. For anyone interested in diving into programming, I would definitely recommend one of the HyperionDev bootcamps (if you sign up from the link, you get a 10% discount too!)

item.title: S2E06 #Weeknotes 05-11 Feb'24
item.description:
Personal Reflections:

This week was a tapestry of personal growth and introspection. Launching my fortnightly newsletter focusing on the first-gen Indian immigrant experience proved daunting. The commitment to a regular cadence felt more intimidating than starting a blog with its flexible schedule. But like any good product manager, I embraced the challenge, navigating the “oscillation and consideration of risks alongside ambitions.” Now, the focus lies on marketing the newsletter and ensuring its value for both myself and my subscribers.

item.title: S2E05 #Weeknotes 29 Jan-04 Feb'24
item.description:
Hi Everyone,

I took a couple of days off from work and spent some time Coding, catching up with Rach, and generally getting ready to launch a newsletter focusing on my experiences as a first-gen expat in a new country. After launching into Jan, taking a couple of days off has been good to get perspective. There’s a general sense that companies are struggling, with the pendulum swinging back from inordinate cash at disposal to profitability and efficiencies. The tightening of belts is healthy, though uncomfortable for some. This leads to a lot of reflection, defensiveness, and even shutting down. I see this in every sphere, and perhaps something we can all do is acknowledge that we’re in this together and need to look after ourselves more.

item.title: Managing T/Programme Managers
item.description:
What expectations would you set to manage your team of (Technical) Programme or Project Managers effectively?

Intro - Management by Exception

Micromanagement can stifle creativity and hinder progress. On the other hand, not supporting Programme Managers in effectively executing technical programmes and projects pro-actively could result in heavy losses. Over the last decade of managing technical programmes and managers, I developed a set of expectations building on the Management by Exception (MBE) principles. Embracing this philosophy for technical programme managers (T/PgMs) can empower them with clear expectations and autonomy, intervening only when necessary. This document outlines the “absolute musts” for T/PgMs using the MBE framework, with measurable tolerances and proactive measures to guide their actions and your monitoring.
